standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that exhibits the congruence between them.

question.content: Triangles $\triangle XYZ$ and $\triangle ABC$ are congruent. The side length of each square on the grid is $1$ unit.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $\triangle XYZ$ onto $\triangle ABC$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation $2$ units to the right and $10$ units up, then a reflection over the line $\overleftrightarrow{AC}$. | A translation $6$ units to the right and $6$ units up, then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $B$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at ten, ten, point B at eight, eight, and Point C at two, ten. Triangle X Y Z has point X at the origin, point Y at two, two, and point Z at eight, zero.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $\triangle XYZ$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

In Sequence A we perform a translation $2$ units to the right and $10$ units up...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a reflection over the line $\overleftrightarrow{AC}$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $\triangle XYZ$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at ten, ten, point B at eight, eight, and Point C at two, ten. The pre image of triangle X Y Z has point X at the origin, point Y at two, two, and point Z at eight, zero. The image of triangle X Y Z has point X at two, ten, point Y at four, twelve, and point Z at ten, ten. There is a green line that highlight the shift two units right and ten units up.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at ten, ten, point B at eight, eight, and Point C at two, ten. The pre image of triangle X Y Z has point X at two, ten, point Y at four, twelve, and point Z at ten, ten. There is horizontal line on side AC that the leads to the image of triangle X Y Z which has has point X at two, ten, point Y at four, eight, and point Z at ten, ten.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a translation $6$ units to the right and $6$ units up...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $B$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $\triangle XYZ$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at ten, ten, point B at eight, eight, and Point C at two, ten. The pre image of triangle X Y Z has point X at the origin, point Y at two, two, and point Z at eight, zero. The image of triangle X Y Z has point X at the six, six, point Y at eight, eight, and point Z at fourteen, six. There is a green line that highlight the shift six units right and six units up.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at ten, ten, point B at eight, eight, and Point C at two, ten. The pre image of triangle X Y Z has point X at the six, six, point Y at eight, eight, and point Z at fourteen, six. The image of triangle X Y Z has point X at ten, ten, point Y at eight, eight, and Point Z at two, ten, which perfectly overlaps triangle A B C. There are half circle green arrows from the point X on the pre-image to point A and from point Z on the pre-image to point C.

hints.content: In conclusion, only sequence B maps $\triangle XYZ$ onto $\triangle ABC$.  *Note:* There are many other possible combinations of transformations that would also map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Triangles $\triangle DEF$ and $\triangle ABC$ are congruent.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $\triangle DEF$ onto $\triangle ABC$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation along the directed line segment $\overline{DB}$. then a $90\degree$ rotation about point $B$. | A $90\degree$ rotation about point $F$, then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{FC}$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at seven, ten, point B at zero, ten, and Point C at two, six. Triangle D E F has point D at seven, seven, point E at seven, zero, and point F at eleven, two.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $\triangle DEF$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

In Sequence A we perform a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{DB}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a $90\degree$ rotation about point $B$ (recall that a rotation by a positive angle is counterclockwise).    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $\triangle DEF$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at seven, ten, point B at zero, ten, and Point C at two, six. The pre-image of Triangle D E F has point D at seven, seven, point E at seven, zero, and point F at eleven, two. The image of Triangle D E F has point D at zero, ten, point E at zero, three, and point F at four, five. There is a green line that highlight the shift seven units left and three units up.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at seven, ten, point B at zero, ten, and Point C at two, six. The pre-image of Triangle D E F has point D at zero, ten, point E at zero, three, and point F at four, five. There is a green line that highlight the shift seven units left and three units up. The image of Triangle D E F rotates ninety degrees about point B and has point D at zero, ten, point E at seven, ten, and point F at five, fourteen.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a $90\degree$ rotation about point $F$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{FC}$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $\triangle DEF$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at seven, ten, point B at zero, ten, and Point C at two, six. The pre-image of Triangle D E F has point D at seven, seven, point E at seven, zero, and point F at eleven, two. The image of Triangle D E F is rotated ninety degrees about point F has point D at six, negative two, point E at thirteen, negative two, and point F at eleven, two.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at seven, ten, point B at zero, ten, and Point C at two, six. The pre-image of Triangle D E F has point D at six, negative two, point E at thirteen, negative two, and point F at eleven, two. The image of Triangle D E F has point D at negative three, two, point E at four, two, and point F at two, six. There is a green line that highlight the shift nine units left and four units up.

hints.content: In conclusion, neither of the sequences maps $\triangle DEF$ onto $\triangle ABC$.  *Note:* There are many possible combinations of transformations that would map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Quadrilaterals $LMNO$ and $ABCD$ are congruent. The side length of each square on the grid is $1$ unit.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $LMNO$ onto $ABCD$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation $6$ units to the left and $1$ unit up, then a reflection over the horizontal line through point $A$. | A $90\degree$ rotation about point $O$, then a translation $6$ units to the left and $1$ unit up.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, ten, point B at five, twelve, Point C at six, thirteen, and Point D at nine, thirteen. Quadrilateral L M N O has point L at fourteen, five, point M at twelve, five, point N at eleven, six, and point O at eleven, nine.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $LMNO$ onto $ABCD$.

In Sequence A we perform a translation $6$ units to the left and $1$ unit up...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a reflection over the horizontal line through point $A$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $LMNO$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, ten, point B at five, twelve, Point C at six, thirteen, and Point D at nine, thirteen. The pre-image of Quadrilateral L M N O has point L at fourteen, five, point M at twelve, five, point N at eleven, six, and point O at eleven, nine. The image of Quadrilateral L M N O has point L at eight, six, point M at six, six, point N at five, seven, and point O at five, ten. There is a green line that highlight the shift six units left and one unit up.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, ten, point B at five, twelve, Point C at six, thirteen, and Point D at nine, thirteen. The pre-image of Quadrilateral L M N O has point L at eight, six, point M at six, six, point N at five, seven, and point O at five, ten. The image of Quadrilateral L M N O reflects over a horizontal line passing through point A. Point L is at eight, fourteen, point M is at six, fourteen, point N is at five, thirteen, and point O is at five, ten.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a $90\degree$ rotation about point $O$ (recall that a rotation by a positive angle is counterclockwise)...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation $6$ units to the left and $1$ unit up.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $LMNO$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, ten, point B at five, twelve, Point C at six, thirteen, and Point D at nine, thirteen. The pre-image of Quadrilateral L M N O has point L at fourteen, five, point M at twelve, five, point N at eleven, six, and point O at eleven, nine. It it rotated ninety degrees about point O to form the image of Quadrilateral L M N O with a point L at fifteen, twelve, point M at fifteen, ten, point N at fourteen, nine, and point O at eleven, nine.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, ten, point B at five, twelve, Point C at six, thirteen, and Point D at nine, thirteen. The pre-image of Quadrilateral L M N O with a point L at fifteen, twelve, point M at fifteen, ten, point N at fourteen, nine, and point O at eleven, nine. The image of Quadrilateral L M N O with a point L at nine, thirteen, point M at nine, eleven, point N at eight, ten, and point O at five, ten. There is a green line that highlight the shift six units left and one unit up.

hints.content: In conclusion, neither of the sequences maps $LMNO$ onto $ABCD$.  *Note:* There are many possible combinations of transformations that would map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Quadrilaterals $STUV$ and $ABCD$ are congruent. The side length of each square on the grid is $1$ unit.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $STUV$ onto $ABCD$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation $7$ units to the left and $2$ units up, then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $C$. | A $180\degree$ rotation about point $T$, then a translation $3$ units to the right and $8$ units up.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, fourteen, point B at eleven, thirteen, Point C at six, ten, and Point D at four, eleven. Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at fourteen, four, point T at eight, five, point U at thirteen, eight, and point V at fifteen, seven.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $STUV$ onto $ABCD$.

In Sequence A we perform a translation $7$ units to the left and $2$ units up...   [[☃ image 2]]  ...then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $C$.    [[☃ image 1]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $STUV$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, fourteen, point B at eleven, thirteen, Point C at six, ten, and Point D at four, eleven. Pre-Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at seven, six, point T at one, seven, point U at six, ten, and point V at eight, nine. It is rotated one hundred eighty degrees about point C where the Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at five, fourteen, point T at eleven, thirteen, point U at six, ten, and point V at four, eleven.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, fourteen, point B at eleven, thirteen, Point C at six, ten, and Point D at four, eleven. Pre-Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at fourteen, four, point T at eight, five, point U at thirteen, eight, and point V at fifteen, seven. The Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at seven, six, point T at one, seven, point U at six, ten, and point V at eight, nine. There is a green line that highlight the shift seven units left and two units up.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a $180\degree$ rotation about point $T$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation $3$ units to the right and $8$ unit up.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $STUV$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, fourteen, point B at eleven, thirteen, Point C at six, ten, and Point D at four, eleven. Pre-Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at fourteen, four, point T at eight, five, point U at thirteen, eight, and point V at fifteen, seven. It is rotated to form the Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at two, six, point T at eight, five, point U at three, two, and point V at one, three.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, fourteen, point B at eleven, thirteen, Point C at six, ten, and Point D at four, eleven. Pre-Image Quadrilateral S T U V has point S at two, six, point T at eight, five, point U at three, two, and point V at one, three.  The Image of Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at five, fourteen, point B at eleven, thirteen, Point C at six, ten, and Point D at four, eleven. There is a green line that highlight the shift three units right and eight units up.

hints.content: In conclusion, both sequences map $STUV$ onto $ABCD$.  *Note:* There are many other possible combinations of transformations that would also map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Quadrilaterals $EFGH$ and $ABCD$ are congruent.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $EFGH$ onto $ABCD$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A $-90\degree$ rotation about point $H$, then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{HD}$. | A $-90\degree$ rotation about point $F$, then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{FA}$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at fourteen, nine, point B at fourteen, six, Point C at eleven, two, and Point D at eleven, five. Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at two, thirteen, point F at five, thirteen, point G at nine, ten, and point H at six, ten.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $EFGH$ onto $ABCD$.

In Sequence A we perform a $-90\degree$ rotation about point $H$ (recall that a rotation by a negative angle is clockwise)...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{HD}$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $EFGH$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at fourteen, nine, point B at fourteen, six, Point C at eleven, two, and Point D at eleven, five. The Pre-Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at two, thirteen, point F at five, thirteen, point G at nine, ten, and point H at six, ten. It is rotated negative ninety degrees about point H to form the Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at nine, fourteen, point F at nine, five, point G at six, seven, and point H at six, ten.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at fourteen, nine, point B at fourteen, six, Point C at eleven, two, and Point D at eleven, five. The Pre-Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at nine, fourteen, point F at nine, five, point G at six, seven, and point H at six, ten. The Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at fourteen, nine, point F at fourteen, six, point G at eleven, two, and Point H at eleven, five. There is a green line that highlight the shift five units right and five units down.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a a $-90\degree$ rotation about point $F$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{FA}$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $EFGH$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at fourteen, nine, point B at fourteen, six, Point C at eleven, two, and Point D at eleven, five. The Pre-Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at two, thirteen, point F at five, thirteen, point G at nine, ten, and point H at six, ten. It is rotated negative ninety degrees about point F to form the Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at five, sixteen, point F at five, thirteen, point G at two, nine, and point H at two, twelve.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at fourteen, nine, point B at fourteen, six, Point C at eleven, two, and Point D at eleven, five. The Pre-Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at five, sixteen, point F at five, thirteen, point G at two, nine, and point H at two, twelve. The Image Quadrilateral E F G H has point E at fourteen, twelve, point F at fourteen, nine, point G at eleven, five, and point H at eleven, eight. There is a green line that highlight the shift nine units right and four units down.

hints.content: In conclusion, only sequence A maps $EFGH$ onto $ABCD$.  *Note:* There are many other possible combinations of transformations that would also map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Triangles $\triangle UVW$ and $\triangle ABC$ are congruent.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $\triangle UVW$ onto $\triangle ABC$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A $180\degree$ rotation about point $V$, then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{VB}$. | A translation along the directed line segment $\overline{UA}$. then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $A$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at five, seven, point B at five, three, and Point C at two, three. Triangle U V W has point U at eleven, eight, point V at eleven, twelve, and point W at fourteen, twelve.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $\triangle UVW$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

In Sequence A we perform a $180\degree$ rotation about point $V$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{VB}$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $\triangle UVW$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at five, seven, point B at five, three, and Point C at two, three. The pre-image of Triangle U V W has point U at eleven, eight, point V at eleven, twelve, and point W at fourteen, twelve. It is rotated one hundred eighty degrees about point V to form the image of Triangle U V W has point U at eleven, sixteen, point V at eleven, twelve, and point W at eight, twelve.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at five, seven, point B at five, three, and Point C at two, three. The pre-image of Triangle U V W has point U at eleven, sixteen, point V at eleven, twelve, and point W at eight, twelve. The image of Triangle U V W has point U at five, seven, point V at five, three, and point W at two, three. There is a green line that highlight the shift six units left and nine units down.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{UA}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $A$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $\triangle UVW$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at five, seven, point B at five, three, and Point C at two, three. The pre-image of Triangle U V W has point U at eleven, eight, point V at eleven, twelve, and point W at fourteen, twelve. The image of Triangle U V W has point U at five, seven, point V at five, eleven, and point W at eight, eleven.

The pre-image of Triangle U V W has point U at five, seven, point V at five, eleven, and point W at eight, eleven. It is rotated one hundred eighty degrees to form the image of Triangle U V W has point U at five, seven, point V at five, three, and point W at two, three.

hints.content: In conclusion, both sequences map $\triangle UVW$ onto $\triangle ABC$.  *Note:* There are many other possible combinations of transformations that would also map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Triangles $\triangle KLM$ and $\triangle ABC$ are congruent. The side length of each square on the grid is $1$ unit.     **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $\triangle KLM$ onto $\triangle ABC$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation $9$ units to the left and $7$ units down, then a reflection over the line with slope $-1$ through point $C$. | A  reflection over the line $\overleftrightarrow{KL}$, then a translation $3$ units to the left and $1$ unit down.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at eight, eight, point B at ten, six, and Point C at four, six. Triangle K L M has point K at eleven, nine, point L at thirteen, seven, and point M at thirteen, thirteen.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $\triangle KLM$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

In Sequence A we perform a translation $9$ units to the left and $7$ units down...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a reflection over the line with slope $-1$ through point $C$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $\triangle KLM$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at eight, eight, point B at ten, six, and Point C at four, six. The pre-image of triangle K L M has point K at eleven, nine, point L at thirteen, seven, and point M at thirteen, thirteen. The image of triangle K L M has point K at two, two, point L at four, zero, and point M at four, six. There is a green line that highlight the shift nine units left and seven units down.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at eight, eight, point B at ten, six, and Point C at four, six. The pre-image of triangle K L M has point K at two, two, point L at four, zero, and point M at four, six. It is reflected across a line that slants down with a slope of negative one and passes through point C. It forms the image of triangle K L M has point K at eight, eight, point L at ten, six, and point M at four, six.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a reflection over the line $\overleftrightarrow{KL}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation $3$ units to the left and $1$ unit down.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $\triangle KLM$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at eight, eight, point B at ten, six, and Point C at four, six. The pre-image of triangle K L M has point K at eleven, nine, point L at thirteen, seven, and point M at thirteen, thirteen. It is reflected across a line that slants down with a slope of negative one passing through points K and L. The image of triangle K L M has point  K at eleven, nine, point L at thirteen, seven, and point M at seven, seven.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at eight, eight, point B at ten, six, and Point C at four, six. The pre-image of triangle K L M has point  K at eleven, nine, point L at thirteen, seven, and point M at seven, seven. The image of triangle K L M has point  K at eight, eight, point L at ten, six, and point M at four, six. There is a green line that highlight the shift three units left and one unit down.

hints.content: In conclusion, both sequences map $\triangle KLM$ onto $\triangle ABC$.  *Note:* There are many other possible combinations of transformations that would also map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Triangles $\triangle PQR$ and $\triangle ABC$ are congruent. The side length of each square on the grid is $1$ unit.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $\triangle PQR$ onto $\triangle ABC$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A $180\degree$ rotation about point $R$, then a translation $2$ units to the right and $6$ units up. | A translation $4$ units to the right and $6$ units up, then a reflection over the horizontal line through point $A$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at nine, fourteen, point B at twelve, ten, and Point C at eight, ten. Triangle P Q R has point P at five, eight, point Q at two, four, and point R at six, four.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $\triangle PQR$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

In Sequence A we perform a $180\degree$ rotation about point $R$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation $2$ units to the right and $6$ units up.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $\triangle PQR$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at nine, fourteen, point B at twelve, ten, and Point C at eight, ten. The pre-image of triangle P Q R has point P at five, eight, point Q at two, four, and point R at six, four. It is rotated one hundred eighty degrees about point R to form the image of triangle P Q R has point P at ten, four, point Q at seven, zero, and point R at six, four.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at nine, fourteen, point B at twelve, ten, and Point C at eight, ten. The pre-image of triangle P Q R has point P at ten, four, point Q at seven, zero, and point R at six, four. The image of triangle P Q R has point P at twelve, ten, point Q at nine, six, and point R at eight, ten. There is a green line that highlight the shift two units right and six units up.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a translation $4$ units to the right and $6$ units up...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a reflection over the horizontal line through point $A$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $\triangle PQR$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at nine, fourteen, point B at twelve, ten, and Point C at eight, ten. The pre-image of triangle P Q R has point P at five, eight, point Q at two, four, and point R at six, four. The image of triangle P Q R has point P at nine, fourteen, point Q at six, ten, and point R at ten, ten. There is a green line that highlight the shift four units right and six units up.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at nine, fourteen, point B at twelve, ten, and Point C at eight, ten. The pre-image of triangle P Q R has point P at nine, fourteen, point Q at six, ten, and point R at ten, ten. It is reflected over a horizontal line that passes through point A making a triangle P Q R that is above triangle A B C instead of mapping onto it.

hints.content: In conclusion, neither of the sequences maps $\triangle PQR$ onto $\triangle ABC$.  *Note:* There are many possible combinations of transformations that would map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Triangles $\triangle MNO$ and $\triangle ABC$ are congruent.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $\triangle MNO$ onto $\triangle ABC$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation along the directed line segment $\overline{NB}$, then a reflection over the vertical line through point $B$. | A reflection over the vertical line $\overleftrightarrow{MO}$, then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{MB}$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at two, fourteen, point B at five, fourteen, and Point C at two, ten. Triangle M N O has point M at thirteen, nine, point N at ten, nine, and point O at thirteen, five.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $\triangle MNO$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

In Sequence A we perform a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{NB}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a reflection over the vertical line through point $B$.   [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $\triangle MNO$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a reflection over the vertical line $\overleftrightarrow{MO}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{MB}$.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $\triangle MNO$ onto $\triangle ABC$.

question.content: Quadrilaterals $HIJK$ and $ABCD$ are congruent. The side length of each square on the grid is $1$ unit.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $HIJK$ onto $ABCD$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A $270\degree$ rotation about point $J$, then a translation $9$ units to the right and $8$ units down. | A reflection over the line $\overleftrightarrow{HI}$, then a translation $6$ units to the right and $3$ units down.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at nine, four, point B at eleven, six, Point C at fourteen, six, and Point D at fourteen, four. Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at three, seven, point I at five, nine, point J at five, twelve, and point K at three, twelve.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $HIJK$ onto $ABCD$.

In Sequence A we perform a $270\degree$ rotation about point $J$ (recall that a rotation by a positive angle is counterclockwise)...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation $9$ units to the right and $8$ units down.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence does *not* map $HIJK$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at nine, four, point B at eleven, six, Point C at fourteen, six, and Point D at fourteen, four. The pre-image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at three, seven, point I at five, nine, point J at five, twelve, and point K at three, twelve. It is rotated two hundred seventy degrees about point J to form the image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at zero, fourteen, point I at two, twelve, point J at five, twelve, and point K at five, fourteen.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at nine, four, point B at eleven, six, Point C at fourteen, six, and Point D at fourteen, four. The pre-image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at zero, fourteen, point I at two, twelve, point J at five, twelve, and point K at five, fourteen. The image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at nine, six, point I at eleven, four, point J at fourteen, four, and point K at fourteen, six. There is a green line that highlight the shift nine units right and eight units down.

hints.content: In Sequence B we perform a reflection over the line $\overleftrightarrow{HI}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a translation $6$ units to the right and $3$ units down.    [[☃ image 2]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $HIJK$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at nine, four, point B at eleven, six, Point C at fourteen, six, and Point D at fourteen, four. The pre-image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at three, seven, point I at five, nine, point J at five, twelve, and point K at three, twelve. It is reflected over the line H I to create the image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at three, seven, point I at five, nine, point J at eight, nine, and point K at eight, seven.

The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at nine, four, point B at eleven, six, Point C at fourteen, six, and Point D at fourteen, four. The pre-image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at three, seven, point I at five, nine, point J at eight, nine, and point K at eight, seven. The image of Quadrilateral H I J K has point H at nine, four, point I at eleven, six, point J at fourteen, six, and point K at fourteen, four.

hints.content: In conclusion, only sequence B maps $HIJK$ onto $ABCD$.  *Note:* There are many other possible combinations of transformations that would also map the figure onto the image.

question.content: Quadrilaterals $ABCD$ and $WXYZ$ are congruent.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $WXYZ$ onto $ABCD$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A reflection over the vertical line $\overleftrightarrow{WX}$, then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $W$, and then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{WA}$. | A translation over the directed line segment $\overline{WA}$, then a reflection over the horizontal line through point $A$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at fourteen, eight, point B at fourteen, eleven, Point C at twelve, thirteen, and Point D at ten, thirteen. Quadrilateral W X Y Z has point W at eight, nine, point X at eight, six, point Y at six, four, and point Z at four, four.

hints.content: Let's perform each of the sequences and see if they map $WXYZ$ onto $ABCD$.

In Sequence A we perform a reflection over the vertical line $\overleftrightarrow{WX}$...    [[☃ image 1]]  ...then a $180\degree$ rotation about point $W$...    [[☃ image 2]]  ...then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{WA}$.    [[☃ image 3]]  We can see that this sequence *does* map $WXYZ$ onto $ABCD$.

images.alt: The first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. The pre-image Quadrilateral W X Y Z has point W at eight, nine, point X at eight, six, point Y at ten, four, and point Z at twelve, four. It is rotated one hundred eighty degrees about point W to make the image Quadrilateral W X Y Z with point W at eight, nine, point X at eight, twelve, point Y at six, fourteen, and point Z at four, fourteen.

question.content: Quadrilaterals $ABCD$ and $KLMN$ are congruent.      **Which of the following sequences of transformations maps $KLMN$ onto $ABCD$?**  Sequence A | Sequence B :- | :- A translation along the directed line segment $\overline{MA}$, then a reflection over the horizontal line through point $A$. | A reflection over the vertical line through point $N$, then a translation along the directed line segment $\overline{NB}$.
